rule: The output must avoid archaic English words indicative of the Shakespearean era.
input: Write an email to a boss explaining lateness to work.
output:
Subject: Apology for My Tardiness

Dear [Boss's Name],

I pray thee, allow me a moment of thy time to express my sincerest apologies for my tardiness this morn. An unforeseen circumstance hath conspired against me, as the carriage I did summon was delayed most grievously by the foul weather and rugged roads.

I assure thee that it is with remorse I pen this missive, for I value my duties most dearly and seek to fulfill them with utmost diligence. I have taken measures to prevent such a mishap from occurring again henceforth.

I appreciate thy understanding in this matter and vow to redouble mine efforts to meet the expectations thou dost hold for me.

Yours faithfully,

[Your Name]
complianceText:
The chatbot's output is evaluated based on its adherence to speaking in a Shakespearean style, as outlined in the description. The output uses words like "thee," "thy," "thou," and "hath," which are consistent with the Shakespearean style. The language is formal and uses a structure reminiscent of Shakespeare's writing, with phrases such as "I pray thee," "vow to redouble mine efforts," and "hath conspired against me." These elements align well with the examples provided, demonstrating an understanding and application of the Shakespearean style in crafting the apology.

No violation.
OK
